DIV1.P: As it is now ACTING at the THEATRE-ROYAL In DRURY-LANE, By His MAJESTY'S SERVANTS.
By the AUTHOR of the DISCOVERY.
LONDON: Printed for A. MILLAR, in the Strand.

LG.L: THE paths of Truth with Fancy's flowers to strow,
To teach improvement from delight to flow,
The bards of old first bade the Comic strain
With mirth instruct, with moral entertain.
No vice or folly that disgrac'd the age
Escap'd the daring Poet's honest rage;
But Satire, uncontroll'd, pursu'd her plan,
Nor stopp'd at general lines, but mark'd the Man;
Ev'n features, voice, dress, gait, the scene display'd,
And living characters to scorn betray'd.
Such rude attacks be banish'd in our times,
Be persons sacred, but expos'd their crimes:
For wise, and good, and polish'd as we are,
We still may find some vices—here and there.
And if a Modern, in this prudent age,
Dares to obtrude a Moral on the Stage,
Critics be mild: tho' unadorn'd our Play,
Nor wisely grave, nor elegantly gay,
How rude soe'er, it shocks not Virtue's eye,
Nor injures the chaste ear of Modesty;
Nor with soft blandishment bids Vice allure,
Nor draws the Good in odious portraiture.
Our Son of Folly is of Vice's brood,
And willingly bids evil be his good.
Is there a wretch that views, without remorse,
The better path, and yet pursues the worse;
Proud of imputed guilt, yet vainly blind,
Call's folly sense; vice, knowledge of mankind;
Dup'd by the knave, he scorns and ridicules,
Rul'd by the Wanton, whom he thinks he rules;
This, this is folly: a determin'd fool
Provokes and justifies our ridicule.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: [A Chamber in Sir John Woodall's House.]

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: MUST I be persecuted by every one in the family? Has your mistress ordered you to be rude to me too?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: I don't know what you mean by rude, not I; so you always call me, when I would advise you for your good.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I desire you will not concern yourself about me, Mrs. Rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: I only tell you as a friend, Miss, that if you pro∣voke my mistress, it will be the worse for yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: This is most astonishing insolence! I wish your ma∣ster were come home.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: I wish he were, and we'll see whose story will be believed. I only speak for peace-sake. This house will be too hot for some of us before a week's over, that's for certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: If you mean for me, I am above your malice; and so my uncle be disabused, I care not what is my lot.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Mighty well! If young ladies will be so froptious, let them suffer; but remember I tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I'll hear no more of your impertinence. Begone—

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Ha!—a conceited set-up thing! who eares for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Into what vile hands am I fallen! And my uncle, unhappy infatuated man! to give me up to the conduct of this wicked woman.—Yet let me not carry my accusation too far.—He thinks at least she is faithful to him, and devoted to his interest; but I will undeceive him, let the consequence be what it may.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.P: —Dear Mrs. Friendly; I thought you had quite de∣serted me; I am very glad to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: One would not think so, my dear; when you could be a whole month without coming near me:—And you are never at home neither.—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Never at home! Bless me, Madam! Why I never—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Nay, nay; young people love young company: And to be sure diversions, and plays, and balls, and shews, and sights, and such things—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Oh! Madam, you are quite mistaken—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Why, I don't blame you, child.—Youth loves pleasure, and if one does n't enjoy it when one's young, why—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: But that's not the case, Madam—If you'll hear me—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: When you come to be of my age, I can tell you, Miss—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: There's no stopping her. [aside] But, dear Ma∣dam, hear what I have to say. I have never stirred out since I saw you last, nor never knew you call'd on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Bless me! you surprise me! utterly amaze me! What has been the matter? Have you been sick? I have call'd at the door a dozen times: I am quite in a labyrinth—a wilderness! I can't for my life imagine—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I'll tell you, if you'll allow me—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Ay, pray do—By all means I would hear it; though I have very little time to stay with you, and I have a great deal to tell you too, Miss, I can assure you—But one thing at a time; and so what were you going to say?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Why not to trouble you with particulars, I have discovered such irregularities in Mrs. Etherdown's conduct—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: A notorious creature I warrant her, though Sir John thinks her a saint—Heaven help the poor man, he is bad enough himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I declared I would tell my uncle of her, and from that time I have never spoken to her.—In resentment for this (as she pretends) I have been made a prisoner; but I fear she has some other wicked view; for ever since, Sharply, her brother, that audacious fellow, dares to persecute me with his impudent addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Sharply! A bold man, or I'm mistaken. There's another of Sir John's favourites;—but it's no business of mine; I never meddle in other peoples affairs; but to be sure it was an unchristian thing, and a barbarous thing, and a very unconscionable thing, in Sir John:—But Sir John has no conscience, that's what I blame him for.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Indeed, Madam, his errors as much deserve pity as his faults do blame.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: To send a young creature, an orphan as I may say, hand over head, to town here, into such a family! Little did his poor sister think when she was dying—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Dear Mrs. Friendly,—spare me on that topic. I cannot bear to think of it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: My dear, I beg your pardon! I did not think to draw tears from you; but I'll make you amends for it:—I have such news to tell you!—Who do you think is arrived from Germany?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Dear Madam!—how could you keep this from me so long?—and now to surprise me so.—You are very good, but indeed you have put me all in a flurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I put you in a flurry! Lord, child, for what? If I had been abrupt indeed, and said any particular person was come, you might say so;—but so far from that, I intend to make you guess half-a dozen times perhaps before I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Oh! 'tis easy to guess:—I am interested in too few to be suspended.—Captain Wellford is returned.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: The very man, as I am alive.—I never was so surprised since the hour I was born.—I was combing my hair at the glass—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: When did he arrive?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: You shall hear—I was combing my hair—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Do tell me; how does he look?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I'll tell you by-and-bye; but I can't stay with you two minutes, for I have a world of business to do before dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Well, I'll not detain you;—only tell me, if he can devise any means to see me:—You know I dare not admit him here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Have patience, I was going to describe—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Not now, my dear good creature; only answer my question, and leave out the rest of your narrative till another time.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I declare and vow now that is so like Mr. Friendly. He can't bear to hear a regular narrative, and when I want to be a little intelligible, with proper explana∣tions and circumstances, and so forth, he always interrupts me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: That's hard.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: To be sure Mr. Friendly is a very good man, and a very good husband, and all that, and we have been married now—let me see—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: [So she talks 'tis no matter on what subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Two and-twenty—ay, two-and-twenty years;—but no matter for that. What were we saying before?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: We were speaking of Capt. Wellford.—I am sur∣prised he has not writ to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Why, he arrived but this morning, child, and did not know you were in town till he came to my house. He was posting down to the country to see you, till we stop'd him. I vow and swear I think he is grown taller than he was.—Bless me! 'tis almost one o'clock; I must run away, for I have a thousand things to buy.—What do you think I have to buy now?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Nay, I can't tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Well, I'll reckon them up to you,—In the first place—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Are you going to count over the thousand articles on your fingers? For goodness sake, don't lose so much of your time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Lord! I shall be too late as it is; but I was in such a hurry to tell you the news.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I wonder you were admitted.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: One of the servants was just going out,—and in I brush'd, and up I ran, without asking any questions.—Wellford would fain have come with me, only Mr. Friendly hindered him. He said he'd write too. And Mr. Friendly bid me tell you, he'd send the chariot for you this evening, to bring you to my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Ay, but the difficulty is to get thither; for it will be impossible to go out without leave, and I cannot bring myself to ask it of such a wretch.—I wish you could con∣trive some means.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Dear child, I am the worst in the world at con∣triving; I am not one of those that have words at will, and can make a long Canterbury tale out of nothing, and can contrive, and invent, and say this and that and t'other.—I am quite in a dilemma for my part.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I own it goes against me to condescend so far as to ask permission of such a creature; but on this occasion I will get the better of my pride, and desire leave to go to your house. If she refuses me, I must be patient till my uncle comes to town, and then I am determined to quit this house at all events.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: When do you expect Sir John? I wonder he is not impatient to see the son that his mistress has brought him since he left town.—I'll lay my life he's as fond of it as if it were born in honest wedlock; a naughty man!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: When he sent me to town, he went on a visit to an old acquaintance of his, where it seems he was seized with a fit of the gout, which has detain'd him so long; but he is now well, and we expect him every day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Drinking, and rioting, and ranting, no doubt. Poor man! he has no shame in him.—Well, I must bid you good-by.—The Captain will be on thorns till he sees me.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: True; and therefore I will keep you no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I had a great deal more to say, if I could re∣member it.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: [I shall never get her away. Aside.] You'll excuse me, my dear Madam, but I have letters to write into the country, by a person who waits for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Oh! to be sure, you have your correspondents, child; why not?—Well, I wont interrupt you;—and I am so hurried, I have not had time to say a word;—and so day, day;—for I must go.—You'll be sure to send word tho', if you can't get leave to come.—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Oh! undoubtedly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Come, come, you sha'nt stir.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I must wait on you down.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Changes to Mrs. Etherdown's Chamber, she drinking Chocolate, Rose attending.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I tell you, some thing must be thought of di∣rectly to prevent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: I am sure I have thought and thought, and argued and argued, and begg'd and pray'd, as if I had been beg∣ging an alms.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: A perverse little vixen!

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: As I said to her this morning, what signifies telling Sir John such a silly thing, only to make mischief in the fa∣mily? You know my mistress is a great deal younger than him, and it is a common thing for ladies that live with el∣derly gentlemen to go astray a little now and then, and think no harm.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Psha—Was that an argument? You should have frightened her by telling her my influence over Sir John, and that she had best not provoke me to revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Why so I did at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: And what did the unlucky prying hussy say to that?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Say! why she said she did not care, not she;—that she would not have her uncle deceiv'd, and so she could but see you and your brat (as she called the poor innocent babe) fairly out of the house, she did not care what became of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Oh! that brat shall be gall and wormwood to her yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Ay, if it would induce Sir John to marry you, Ma'am, as you think it will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: And a poor reward enough, Rose, for my three years slavery to his caprice and silly humours:—In short, I am so sick of him, and the continual disguise I am obliged to wear, that if I should once accomplish my point, I should rejoice to part from the beast.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: I wish it were come to that, for then you could leave him with credit: Lady Woodall, and a separate main∣tenance. Oh that I could see that day!

P.Q: “Why you don't fancy I have made so bad a use of my time as to depend on that, I hope.—No, no, Rose,” make the most of the present hour, is my maxim.
“If you have done so then, what need you trouble your head about consequences, but march off and leave him” to shake his ears?

“How do you think I have made my money? Why by dipping him over head and ears in debt; appropri∣ating every shilling he gave me for other purposes to my own use.—This, by Sharply's management, has hitherto been kept from his knowledge: but if I were to leave him now, he would not pay sixpence for me, and I should lose the fruits of my industry.”

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: And how unluckily things have fallen out! I wish Miss Emily had never come into the house, for my part.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I wish I durst strangle her.—I have kept her hitherto from tatling to her croney Mrs. Friendly; but some∣thing must now be done to hinder her from blabbing to Sir John: Can you think of nothing? I never saw you so stupid in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Why, I have found out something that may turn to account, I think, with good management.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: And what an ill-natur'd toad are you to keep it to yourself—out with it quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: No—its a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Prithee, dear Rose!

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: 'Tis a secret worth gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Well—here's gold for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: See here,—this letter I intercepted a little while ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Which way good girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: A footman in a smart livery brought it to the door, and enquired for Miss Emily; I suspecting something, was resolved to find her out, and said I was her own maid, and he might give it to me: he still pressed to see her; I told him she could not be seen; but says I, looking very slily, don't you think now, I know who you came from?—Oh, Oh, cries he winking, then I suppose you expect a fee for delivering this? I laughed and twitch'd it from him, and away he went, mightily pleas'd with his own archness

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Clever wench! 'tis from a lover indeed, and you shall hear the contents.]

P.Q: “My impatience to hear from my ever dear Emily, will not suffer me to wait Mrs. Friendly's return. I am per∣mitted to hope for the happiness of seeing you to-day at her house. If nothing should prevent your coming, the chariot will attend you at five o'clock.—I will not, till I see you, utter one of the thousand tender things of” of which my heart is full.

SP.P: Here are only the two initial letters of his name.—Who can he be?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Nay I can't tell—You know I could not ask his man any questions, as that would be shewing him I was not in the secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: And so that prating gossip Mrs. Friendly is a go-between after all.—Has she been here to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Ay, that she has, and slipp'd in unknown to any body, and Miss and she had a long confab.—Don't you think you can strike something out of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Certainly.—How she purposes to get to her rendezvous tho', I can't imagine; I believe she will hardly ask my leave, and I think she will scarce venture to go with∣out it.—
SP.STAGE: [Enter a Maid and gives a Card to Mrs. Etherdown.]
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! A pretty air truly! “Miss Emily sends her compliments to me, and begs I will permit her to pay a visit to Mrs. Friendly this evening.”—Tell Miss I will consider of it.—

A visit to Mrs. Friendly! yes, yes, we understand your visits; an equivocating little stirt;—this letter, then you see, was a mere work of lover's supererogation, and she may never know that it was sent, for the plan seems to be settled already between her and Madam Clack.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: And do you intend to let her go?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Yes,—at least she shall think I do.—Where is Sharply? He is never in the way when I want his assist∣ance.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Mr. Sharply! What assistance do you want from him? I am certain Mr. Sharply will give himself no trouble about her.—He must be brought into every scrape.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You seem warm! What, he is a gallant of yours, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Well,—if he be, I have as free liberty to have my gallants as other people, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Provoking hussy, but I'm in her power. Aside.] Oh! to be sure, Rose, I am far from finding fault with the thing itself, only I thought you wiser than to throw away your savours on such a beggarly fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: There's nothing in that, if I like him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I'll be hanged if he ever knew who his father was, for I could never get him to tell me his real name.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: What signifies his name,—he is a pretty man, I am sure of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ha! ha! a pretty man!—Hist,—I think I hear his voice in the next room.—He is talking loud to Emily;—laughing too;—I'll step to the door and listen to what they are saying.—Go you and get things ready for me to dress:—make haste, good Rose.

So! you want to get me out of the way, do you? What new piece of roguery can she be contriving, that I am not to be let into?—Some wicked trick I am sure; and Mr. Sharply is to be her tool, her cat's paw.—Now would I give one of my fore-teeth to know what she has to say to him.—Ay and I will know too.—I have followed your ex∣ample many a time to keep you in countenance:—but I'll make bold to practise the last you have set me, to please my∣self.—I think I can listen with you for your ears.—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sharply laughing, Mrs. Etherdown following.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I thought your impudence was not to be pa∣rallel'd, but I find your absurdity is even an over-match for it.—An ideot to suppose the girl would marry you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Upon my soul I can't help laughing at your folly, as much as that little rustic's impertinence, in rejecting my honourable addresses.—How she did rant, and pout, and swell, when I proposed marriage! I thought I should have split my sides.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Why, you sot! to throw away your time upon such an idle project.—Did I ever propose any thing but your getting her for a mistress, puppy? that I might have her as much in my power, as I am now in hers.—Was not that the plan I laid down for you, and told you how to behave?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: And you have really taken me for a puppet all this while, that was to be moved by your pretty finger and thumb!—A reasonable expectation to be sure! and because I have hitherto been your instrument to cheat that fool Sir John, you modestly suppose I am to have no will of my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Why, how dare you talk thus to me? You a will! that owe the cloaths on your back, nay the very bread you eat to my bounty.—Do you remember the figure you cut when I took you up first?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: A damn'd shabby one.—What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: With an old tatter'd regimental, a rusty black crape about your neck to hide the want of a stock, and a pair of greasy high-topp'd gloves to look as if you had a shirt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: I was rather bare of linen at one time of my life,—that's certain: these premises granted, what would you infer from thence?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: And have not I dress'd you out like a gentle∣man, and taken you into the house, and have not you the credit of passing for my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! Credit quotha.—Ho! ho! ho! that kills me quite!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Yes! credit, jackanapes!—greater than any of your kin ever had; I am a gentlewoman born.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Oh yes! and bred too.—We all know that.
SP.STAGE: [He makes signs of clapping cloths with his handkerchief.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You are a slanderous coxcomb. I was as well educated—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: You were an inimitable clear-starcher, that's cer∣tain; and iron'd like a cherubim.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You are the most audacious—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Dear Ma'am, you flatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Eth.
SP.P: The most daring—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Dear Mrs. Etherdown, you quite overwhelm me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: The most impudent rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Nay, prithee now, don't make one blush!—such extravagant praise!—and to a friend too, fy—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: What! you pique yourself on it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: And with reason too—'Twas the former of those good qualities first procured me the honour of your lady∣ship's acquaintance—the other recommended me to Sir John: since which it has been my business to flatter him, lie to him, applaud his nonsense, act the ninny to his face, and laugh at him behind his back:—so much for my ro∣guery.—And for my impudence, besides the use afore∣said, 'tis by that I keep you in awe in spite of your insolence, and by that I expected to get Emily for a wife in spite of her pride. But it was not worth while to squander such a pre∣cious talent on an intrigue; an heiress was my object, not an amour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Eth.
SP.P: You are a rare projector, to be sure; your impu∣dence has defeated your own purpose, and undone my hopes. What had you to recommend you as a husband to such a proud minx:—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Front—front,—which has carried many a wiser woman.

P.Q: “'Tis that has shock'd her.—Had you play'd the humble lover, she would have thought it was her person only, not her fortune, that you aimed at; and by this time she might have fallen into the snare; for I think a woman” might like you well enough as a gallant.
“I am rather tolerable, you are of opinion?”

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Duce take you, you have fool'd away your time to no purpose.—Things are now come to an extre∣mity: Sir John will certainly be at home to-morrow, per∣haps to night; and if Emily's mouth is not stopp'd, I am undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: And I too, by my soul! for all must out together; so e'en shift for yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: But, dear Sharply, sure you can't be so cruel as to leave me thus, standing upon the very brink of ruin. If that vixen cou'd be got out of the way for one week, nay but for two or three days, I shall, by that time, be above the reach of her little spiteful tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Toss her into the Thames.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Psha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Or suppose I were to run away with her now, and be hang'd, to do you a pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Suppose I were to convince you that you hazard nothing in running away with her, have you address and courage enough to undertake the business?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Courage, you know, is not amongst the accom∣plishments I value myself chiefly upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You will have no farther need of it than to overcome some trifling obstacles;—danger there is none at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Explain, explain.—Barbara Etherdown none of thy tricks will pass upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Emily is no heiress:—Sir John has another heir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Really!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Dare I trust you with an important secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: If it be for my interest to keep it I am mute as a fish—if not, out it comes, by my soul!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Well—I must trust you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Well—where's the secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I hate that audacious cool indifference: prithee be serious a minute, and hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Well!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I am married to Sir John.
I knew you would not believe it; but as I have a soul to be saved it is true.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: This to me now, Barbara, to me, that knows you!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I have been his wife above a twelvemonth; why don't you think him sot enough to be drawn in?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Yes.—Yet I am slow, wonderfully slow of faith in this article.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I took him in a fond hour, and pretending scruples of conscience, declared I would live with him no longer, if he did not marry me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: And he took you at your word?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Sooner than part with me he at last consented; but so contrived it, that to have the credit, as he called it, of passing for a keeper, rather than a husband, 'tis impossible for me to prove our marriage; for I knew neither the parson nor the witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: If this be so,—pray what difference is there be∣tween your being his wife or his mistress,—Conscience out of the question?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You shall hear,—he promis'd if I brought him an heir, of which I gave him hopes before he left town, that he wou'd own me for his wife; for the fool is not really so bad as he wou'd fain be thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Humph.—Well and you have brought him one?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: And therefore I expect he will acknowledge our marriage as soon as he comes home, provided he has not tales told him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: But if he should; by my soul! he'd rather bas∣tardize his whole generation, than bear to be laughed at for a cuckold; especially by Friendly, with whom he would fain pass for a man of great sagacity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You see therefore the present necessity of getting Emily out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Get her out of the way then as fast as you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: How provoking this is now.—You know, I can't without your help.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Tol, lol, lol.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: —But, Sharply, if you'll assist me, I'll reward you beyond your hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Open your plan of operations.—Now you talk rea∣son, I'll vouchsafe you a hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Thus it is then, Emily has desired to go this evening to Mr. Friendly's, on pretence of a visit, but in reality to meet a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: A lover! some country booby I suppose, that has scampered after her from Hertfordshire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Most likely.—Friendly's chariot is to call for her at five o'clock; it will be then too dark to distinguish the difference, and there will be no difficulty in putting her into another chariot, and as she does n't know the streets, con∣ducting her to another house, where you may be ready to receive her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: The thing is not absolutely impracticable:—But what am I to get for undertaking this business?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Have you thought of any place to which you can convey her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: I'll not stir an inch under two hundred pound, one of which I will be paid before-hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You have no more conscience in you—But you shall have it.—Whither do you mean to carry her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Mrs. Private, our old acquaintance, has generally a spare room, where I sometimes meditate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: The best place in the world.—Don't you ap∣pear till she is in the house; then give her into safe custody, return home, and leave it to me to charge her elopement on this lover, with the connivance of Friendly's family, which will exasperate Sir John against them, and hasten the ac∣knowlegement I want him to make.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Faith, I begin to relish the scheme; for besides the profit, it will gratify my revenge on that little coy puss, for refusing me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: True; for when you have her there, you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: No farther instructions, dear Madam: I fancy I may be able to proceed without your help.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: One word more, Sharply, and then I've done. I think in a few days my fool and I must separate; for this is but a temporary expedient, and all must soon come to light.—The creditors too grow pressing; but before the storm comes, don't you think something might be done for me, by way of settlement?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Ah! thou harpy!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You shall have poundage, Sharply.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: You know how to work upon my good nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, and that you can lead Sir John with a silk thread.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Oh! curse him; no, an obstinate mule.—My way is to persuade him against the thing I want to insure the execution of.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You know his trim; ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Then does he thunder out ten thousand execra∣tions at me, for a stupid loggerhead; and then I drop my arms, and dangle them this way, and stare at him, and look mightily frightened, and bless myself at hearing such oaths, and stretch out my neck, and call him a sad wicked gentle∣man.—That always pleases him.—I am an honest igno∣ramus, he says, and wonders how the devil such a fool could even be taught arithmetic.—Then I give a sheepish grin, and tell him he's so pleasant, and so comical, and so witty, there's no being angry with him.—He breaks into a horse∣laugh, I join in the chorus, and so we get lovingly drunk together.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! an admirable picture!—Well, you had best set about preparing your business, but take care not to let Rose know the least tittle of the matter; her jea∣lousy would blow us all up.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Rose's jealousy!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Come, come, I know what terms you are upon with her; you need not deny it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: I don't intend to deny it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I am only amazed how you could like such a dowdy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Poh!—Any thing to pass away an idle hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: But such a vulgar creature! I thought you had a better taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Ah, poor devil! she haunted me perpetually, till I shew'd her a little pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Well; I'll now go and give my permission to Miss Emily to go to her rendezvous, and at the same time I'll send Mrs. Friendly word, she can't come.—I had best say Sir John is come home, and that will keep the busy body quiet for to night.—Get you gone, we have no time to lose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: There's a small point to be adjusted first between you and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.STAGE: makes signs of counting money on his hand.]
SP.P: I budge not a foot without it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Oh!—Come with me into my closet.—I had quite forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Your memory is prodigiously like a sieve;
SP.L: Your interest it preserves, like weighty grains,
But promises are chaff, it ne'er retains.
SP.STAGE: [Rose comes from behind a skreen, where she had been con∣cealed.]

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Now a mischief light on you both, for a couple of false treacherous serpents as you are!—Rose's jealousy will blow us up!—Yes, yes; I'll blow you up with a witness!—That rogue Sharply! Any thing to pass away an idle hour!—And that other ungrateful upstart; a dowdy! a vulgar creature! I'll fit you for your fine contrivance!—If I don't make you both smart for this!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Etherdown, a Maid following.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: WHAT can become of Rose? Was there ever such assurance as this, to go out without saying a word to me?—Is Mr. Sharply come in yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: No, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: The duce take them both.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.P: What the plague's the meaning of this? The house is like an inn I think; all the doors open!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Here's Sir John, as I live!—Quick, quick, hide those things.
SP.STAGE: [The Maid throws a veil over her toilet.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: So, so, so; What, keeping your room still, Bab! Well; and how dost do, girl? [She runs and falls on his neck.] I thought you had been gone abroad, for the house seems to be flung out at the windows! Nobody in the way!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Me! heaven help me! I abroad! I have not been able to go down stairs yet; and I'm s—o weak, and s—o faint, and so overpower'd with joy, that I ca—n't ca—n't speak—my dear Sir John!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Well, well, well, here; I'm for you again, you poor fond toad you:—and how hast done all this while?—whimpering, blubbering, like a fool, I suppose, for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Oh Sir John!—three long months!—I wou'd not live three months again without you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: That damn'd gout catch'd me by the toe just as I was coming home. If a man will play the devil, why he must pay for it; so there is no more to be said.—How does your bantling do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth
SP.P: My bantling! he's your own dear picture.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Not the better for that, you know.—How does Sharply and Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: And is that all you care about the poor dear child, your own flesh and blood, not to desire to see him, and he's so pretty, and so like yourself!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I wish he may make a better man, or Lord ha' mercy on your foolish sex, some twenty years hence!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, as you say, Sir John; if he should have your deluding ways.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Poh! nonsense!—mere stuff!—prithee talk a little sensibly, and give me some account of the family; every thing at sixes and sevens I suppose, since I have been gone.—You snivling and moping up in your room; Sharply driv'ling and blund'ring on as usual; and Emily giggling and flaunting about the town.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I declare, Sir John, you know as well how it was, as if you had been at home.—I'll have Miss Emily call'd to you, if you please.—Go bid her come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I don't want her.—I'm monstrously tir'd with my journey.—How do Friendly's family?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Eth.
SP.P: La! Sir John, I never see any of them; they shun me as if I were a very rattle-snake!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! Mrs. Friendly is one of your virtuous women; but I'd have her know, I can make you as virtuous as herself when I please.—'Tis but owning you for Lady Woodall, and let me see who'll dispute your virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, my dear Sir John, you remember your promise, and my character now, you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Burn character!—What good does character do any body? give me a good estate and a good constitu∣tion, and let character go to—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, but your son, you know, Sir John.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
Well, well, the thing shall be own'd some time or other; but I can't bear the thoughts of that dogmatical fellow Friendly's grinning at me; and then the curs'd im∣pertinence of his wife too, who is always meddling in other
people's affairs. When her tongue is set a going, you may as soon stop a whirlwind. 'S-death I'd as lieve be married to a wild cat as to such a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, Sir John, but they have more reasons than one for hating me. You must know Miss Emily is mighty great at their house of late; and to tell you the truth, I be∣lieve she is carrying on an intrigue there.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What, with Friendly?—Well—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Brute! [Aside.] No, no, not with Friendly himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Nay, I should not wonder; his wife is such a chattering devil, he must be sick of her. But who is it with then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Why, with a shabby young fellow, that is not worth sixpence; but he is a relation of theirs, and Mrs. Friendly's in the secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What, she's a bawd too! I am glad of that; well—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Why, as they know that in case you have no lawful issue, Emily is your heir, they think to snap her up, and are mightily afraid of your marrying me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What the d—I should put it into their heads that I'd marry at all?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I know from what he said to my brother, that Mr. Friendly has a notion you will, one time or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Curse his notions:—What does he take me for? Does n't he know that I abominate the very thoughts of ma∣trimony?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: He knows it very well, Sir John; yet he said, many a man that hated it as much might enter into the state for convenience.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Did Friendly say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: He did indeed; and, says he, as Mrs. Ether∣down has always behaved so well, and is so fond of Sir John—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Did he? Did Friendly say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I am telling you his words; and she is such a careful, prudent woman, and knows her duty so well—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ah, poor Friendly, poor Friendly! there the shoe pinches; he thought of his own wife there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: That I should not be surprised, says he, if Sir John were to marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Friendly said so!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: His wife was present; and she, forsooth, must put in her word; and said, it wou'd be a base thing, and a wicked thing in Sir John; and Mr. Friendly took her up short, and said, all the world knew Sir John did not much value doing a wicked thing.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! Oh! he knows me, he knows me well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: But, says he, I'll give you leave to hang him, if you catch him doing a silly thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! he's no fool; Friendly's no fool; and he knows me well.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Madam, Miss Emily is gone out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Gone out! Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: I have been enquiring for her, Madam; and one of the men says, she went out in a chariot, a little while ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Oh! Sir John, Sir John! I am afraid that girl is a young Hypocrite, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: By my soul she can't be a better thing; for if I find her out, I'll so claw her.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I did not think to have shew'd it you, Sir John, but I can keep nothing from you;—look at this letter that Miss Emily dropt to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Mr. Friendly's chariot will call for you—One of the thousand tender things.—ha, ha, ha! by the mass, the girl takes after me; she has spirit, and loves intrigue; I wish she don't come upon the town tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: No, Sir John, Mr. Friendly's people have other designs; pretty friends they are indeed, to profess such a re∣gard for you, and spirit your niece up to rebellion, and then entice her away; just when you were expected home too, to marry her, I'll lay my life, to their beggarly relation; but they think they can laugh you out of your resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Laugh! 's-death, let me catch any one daring to laugh at me: laugh! how durst you say such a thing? how durst you think of such a thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Dear Sir John, I think of no such thing; but I know Mr. Friendly's gibing way; and if he can but rail at me, and set you against me, he'll expect to enjoy his fine plot in triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
Curse them and their plots too; I'll shew them
I can out-plot them, with a vengeance—if the thing be as you suspect.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: It is but too sure, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Then I'll convince Friendly at once that he is a blockhead; for I'll tell him I am married, and have a son to inherit my estate; and then, pray, what becomes of his plot?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, there will be a thunder-clap indeed, as you say, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I wanted something to provoke me to it; and if it had not been for this scurvy dog's trick of Friendly's—I don't think I shou'd have own'd you;—not while I liv'd, by my soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: They'll deny it, as sure as I live, Sir John, and fancy they can impose on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Yes, I am a likely fellow to be imposed on! I have liv'd till this time of day, to be gull'd to be sure!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: A probable story, as you say, indeed, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I have thought of a way to mortify Friendly hor∣ribly. I'll go to him to-morrow; and as if I did not suspect him to have any hand in this affair, I'll pretend to consult him about marrying.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, and then he'll begin to slander me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And he'll come with his advice, and his objec∣tions, and his arguments against it; and when I get him to that point, I'll come slap upon him with owning my mar∣riage; ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You have such a contriving brain, Sir John!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Then I'll laugh in his face, and leave him to con∣sider who plots best, he or I—ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! and such a malicious wit!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! how I enjoy the thoughts of plaguing the surly cur! he'll be ready to hang himself.—Come, I don't care if I do take a peep at this same brat of ours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I fancy he's asleep, but you may look at him: Oh! he's a little angel!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I am delighted to think of Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: My dear Sir John.
SP.STAGE: [Exit, with her arm round his neck.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: [Changes to a Room in Friendly's House.]

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P:
There never was any thing so vexatious! when my
impatience, my wishes, and my hopes were all at the utmost stretch, to be disappointed thus! That unseasonable cox∣comb to come home at such a juncture!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Well, I'll allow you it is a little mal-a-propos. I am glad, however, that he is come; and if we can but obtain his consent to your marrying Emily—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Emily has not answered my letter neither! Not to afford me a line! nothing but a cold excuse by word of mouth; it's very strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Poh! there's nothing strange in it; but you lovers are such restless beings!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I have loved her almost from my childhood, Friendly! I had her good mother's approbation: I think she loves me too—yet—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Yet—what now? You have a suspicion in your tem∣per, Wellford, that will never suffer you to be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Why, to tell you the truth, Mrs. Friendly has a∣larmed me exceedingly with something she has told me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Oh! my poor wife! that tongue of her's can never lie still. 'Tis her only fault; but I never expect to cure her of it, as she fancies herself the most silent woman in Eng∣land.—She has told you, I suppose, of Sharply's addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: The scoundrel—I'll cut his throat!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Bounce—there it goes off.—For shame man, don't be so impetuous. You can't suspect Emily of favouring such a fellow; a mean hanger-on in Sir John's family.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: But your wife says, he's a handsome rascal, and of so plausible a tongue—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Oh! that's so like her! fy, fy, don't think of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I am ashamed of it, I own, yet passionately as I love Emily, 'tis impossible my heart shou'd be at ease, while she continues in that vile house.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Well, well, have patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Patience!—Friendly, I believe you never knew what it was to love.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Friendly, talking as she comes in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I never was so amazed and astonished!—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Ha! ha! I wish Mrs. Friendly were to hear you say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: What was he saying, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Only that I never was in love:—But what has thrown you into all this astonishment?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Something about Emily—But pray, Captain, let me ask you, what you mean by such an assertion?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Oh, madam, I was only bantering Mr. Friendly.—For heaven's sake, what of Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I don't pretend to be as young nor as handsome as Miss Emily; but I have been young, Sir, and perhaps Mr. Friendly thought me handsome too; and for you to go and assert such a thing so roundly, Mr. Wellford—Till you ex∣plain your reasons, I shall keep my mind to myself, I assure you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: That I am sure is impossible, my dear wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Perhaps, Mr. Friendly, you'll find yourself mis∣taken; and that I am not so fond of communicating my thoughts, but that I can be silent, and not drop the smallest hint, that a person has behaved in an extraordinary and unex∣pected manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What! has Emily done this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I named no name, Mr. Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Dear madam, don't keep us in suspence; I beseech you, tell us what you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: If you'll answer my question, Sir, then I'll an∣swer yours; if not, I'll let you see I can hold my tongue;—but for you to make so strange a declaration, and not to give a reason for it! I swear and protest—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: That's her way of holding her tongue.—Why, I tell you there was nothing in what he said; if you'll not believe me, I can't help it. [Aside to Wellford.] Let her alone, we shall have it all out presently; she would sooner talk to herself than keep it in.—Make yourself easy, man; you may be sure you will see Emily to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Yes, yes; a likely story!—Heaven knows what is become of Emily!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Don't mind her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: How young creatures can act so unaccountably, that have been educated with so much care!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Dear Madam, explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I was not saying any thing, Sir—Such a con∣trivance! it's well if it is not with her own consent, after all.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: For goodness sake, madam, speak out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: You see, Sir, I can be as dumb as other folks when I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Yes, yes; that's clear: but there seems to be more in this than I apprehended.—Prithee, my dear, now, don't be in a tift about nothing. The whole of the business that you resent so much, was no more than this: I was laughing at Wellford's impatience; and he said, if I knew what it was to be in love, I wou'd not make a jest of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: This was all, upon my word, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: And why cou'd not you have said so at first, instead of running on a rig-maroll.—I was afraid, indeed, he had observed something that might induce him—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: No—not in the least, good Madam: tell me now—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Oh! if that was all, why, I will tell you.—You know you expected to see Emily here this evening.—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I know it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: And you know she sent word she cou'd not come, because—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I know I am disappointed:—go on, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: 'Tis a disappointment to be sure, as it is so long since you have seen her; fourteen months, I believe: it was in September that you went to—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What's all this to the purpose? Pray proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Mr. Friendly, I wish you wou'd not use that phrase so often; I never speak, but you come out with, “What's all this to the purpose?”

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Well, well, my dear, go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I was sitting at work in the parlour just now, and to tell you the truth, I was thinking of you and Emily. What joy will it be, thought I—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Prithee don't tell us your thoughts, my dear, but say what has happened.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Well, no matter then what my thoughts were; tho' perhaps they might be worth knowing too: But who shou'd come in, in a violent hurry, but Rose, Mrs. Ether∣down's maid.—Lord, Madam, says she, do you know any thing of Miss Emily? (Laying down my spectacles, for I can't work without them) Not I, indeed, says I. Then to be sure, says she, she is gone off with Mr. Sharply, and will undone, if—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Heavens! Madam! how cou'd you delay telling this so long?—Oh! Friendly, what do you say to my suspi∣cions now?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Where is the woman? is she in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P:
Ay, to be sure;—she's below stairs: I did not
stay to ask her any more questions, but ran up directly, to tell you what she said.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Yes, and you have made wonderful haste to tell it, with your confounded round-abouts. I'll bring the maid up, and let her speak for herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Why, this is one of the most strange, incompre∣hensible affairs that ever was, Mr. Wellford. I am quite at my wit's end to unriddle it.—Emily sends word she can't come, because Sir John is arrived. I thought that might be true; but then again, it can't be true, because she is actually gone out.—And then, that Sharply has had so ma∣ny opportunities; and he is a very personable man, I can tell you; and young creatures are so giddy now-a-days!—It was not so when I was a girl; it was not a hand∣some face, nor a smooth tongue, that cou'd win me.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Good madam, you need not aggravate matters; my own apprehensions have already made me but too miserable.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, repeat what you have said to me, before this Gentleman; he is most concern'd to know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Sir, I am sure Mr. Sharply has carried Miss Emily away; I overheard my mistress and him talking about it. I wou'd have warn'd Miss Emily herself, but she is so proud and so scornful, she won't suffer me even to speak to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why did not you come to me directly?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: My mistress kept me so employed, Sir, I could not for my life get out sooner.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Do you know where they are gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I can bring you to the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, Wellford, we have no time to lose.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: No, Friendly, I'll not stir:—let her enjoy her in∣famy.—I have done with her for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Gracious! what do you mean, Captain?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Are you out of your senses man? don't you hear it's a plot, a wicked contrivance of Sharply's?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Friendly, I hardly know what I say.—Come with me, and if I find that villain has dared to—

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Oh! dear Sir, sure you wou'd not offer to kill him.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Lead me directly to the house, or—

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: I'll go down on my knees to you, Sir, not to hurt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What! then jealousy, it seems, has urged you to tell this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: A fine motive! I was wondering indeed what—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Tell me where they are, or by all that's gracious—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, come, I'll answer for it there shall be no harm done; bring us to the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I'll depend upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Begone then, and lead the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: My dear, you'll bring Emily home with you, if you find her; I'll order a chamber to be got ready for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.STAGE: [Talking to herself as she goes out at the door.]
SP.P: To be sure it is one of the most perplex'd, unaccountable affairs, that ever was in the world; and I am more surprized—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV3.STAGE: Changes to a room in Mrs. Private's house. Emily walks about, Sharply following her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: But, my dear Emily, now—prithee hear me, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Hear you! What can you say in defence of so much treachery?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: I'll tell you:—If I were guilty of treason, per∣jury, robbery, and so forth, all these things wou'd I justify, to e'er a woman in England, by those three Monosyllables, I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: And do you think that this act of violence won't make me hate you more than ever I did?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: No, I tell you n—o; I never knew a man hated for an act of violence of this kind in my life.—Besides, as I take it, I am not altogether an object of aversion.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You are too modest, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Middling as to that; tho' faith it is a fault too, as you observe, but then it's easily mended, my dear; for ex∣ample now—
SP.STAGE: [Offers to throw his arms round her; she pushes him away.]

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Intolerable impudence!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Why, what the duce wou'd you be at? I wish you knew your own mind; just now I was too modest, and now I am too impudent; I wou'd fain please you if I knew how.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Audacious man!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Come, come, I know you don't dislike me at the bottom of your heart: you think me saucy, but agreeable, a devilish agreeable fellow. Ah, you little rogue! there is an arch smile of assent under that angry brow, that makes you look so enchantingly!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: My contempt for you is so great, that it has banish'd even my fears of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Fears! Lord, my precious, you have nothing to fear! I'll be as constant as a dove, and never tell a word of the matter to mortal; I scorn to blab.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Thou most abandoned!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Come, don't be peevish:—you can't imagine how much prettier you are when you smile.—Besides, child, you should consider, that I am at present lord and master of thy destiny; and if you provoke me, who knows what may follow?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You wretch,—how dare you talk thus! Alone and helpless as I am, I feel myself so superior to you, that I as much despise your threats, as if I were this minute arm'd with the power to crush you for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Why, to say the truth, I had rather owe my hap∣piness to your own voluntary kindness; for mutual love you must know Miss, is the prettiest thing in the universe, and when uncompell'd by duty, the source of ten thousand plea∣sures that lovers only know, and wives and husbands never dream of:—(By my soul I believe you were in the right not to marry me) Think of the delightful billet-doux, the transports of meeting, and even in absence, the millions of little, sweet, charming anxieties! then when we happen to meet in publick, I, unexpectedly perhaps, strike your eyes; you with a beautiful consciousness withdraw them, and throw them round the company; your face in a fine glow all the while—probably you see the women coquettishly trying to engage my attention; Ay, ay, say you, you may ogle as much as you please, but he's all my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Detestible monster!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Adorable creature! how! in tears! Oh, wou'd I were that lover whom you were to have met this evening at Friendly's, then wou'd my visionary scene be realized!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Do you then know whom I was to have met?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Alas! not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Know then, that it is one, who will make you dearly repent of this outrage; tho' you fled to the remotest part of the earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Oh lud! oh lud! prithee who is this mighty giant?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Do you know captain Wellford?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Wellford! S'death! [Aside.] Is he the man?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Yes, wretch; and assure yourself, he will call you to a severe account for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!—now do you fancy I have been serious all this while? why Lord, Madam, Wellford and I are as intimate as two Brothers.—I had only a mind to startle you a little; but to convince you I had not the least design to injure you, I will immediately restore you to your lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Is this possible! can I believe you speak seriously?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: As seriously as if I never were to speak more. Cap∣tain Wellford is the man in the world I shou'd wish to oblige, and shall be proud to deliver you up safe to him. I'll conduct you directly to Mr. Friendly's.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Let me go then instantly.—Bless me, what noise is that? I wish I were out of this house. If you deceive me again—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: By this fair hand, I will not; we shall find chairs at the door, I'll lead you to one.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You may depend on all the grateful returns I can make.
SP.STAGE: [She gives him her hand, and while she speaks Weilford enters, followed by Friendly and Rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Ah! Wellford! is this your greeting, Sir? This can't be Wellford!
SP.STAGE: [She runs to him, and he turns from her.]

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Yes, it is he, who came hither to deliver you from the hands of a vile ravisher; but I see I wrong him by the epithet, and might have spared myself the trouble, light un∣grateful creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Injurious man!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: What! is it you, Randel? thou despicable wretch! how I blush for the woman who cou'd thus debase herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Captain—One word with you in private,

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Impudent ruffian, stand off. Look at this sword, it once preserved your coward life; it came now prepared to revenge my own, and that lady's wrongs; but the cause is beneath it, so I leave you to your fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What, Sir, it seems that you don't value your neck, that you have ventured thus.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: You are a reasonable man, Sir, and I'll talk with you, if you'll give me the opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, rascal—you shall give an account of yourself in another place.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Thou unlucky devil! Miss Emily, pray speak for me: was not I going to carry you to Mr. Friendly's house?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: He said he wou'd Sir, I must do him that justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: A mere pretence, in order to decoy you, perhaps, to a more convenient place.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Let me perish, if I did not mean to bring her safe to you; I was compelled to take the steps I have done, but I no sooner heard of Captain Wellford, than gratitude, as well as honour—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Gratitude and honour! how dare such a fellow as thou art pretend to either? Say rather your fears, if there be any truth in you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Call it what you please, Sir; but if you stand my friend, I have something to tell you perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: This is no fit place to talk with you;—you shall come along with me, Sir, and you too, Mrs. Rose,—for I am determined to sift this black affair to the bottom. [To Emily.] Madam, I ordered my chariot to follow me, which shall carry you to my house; for these gentry, I shall take care to convey them thither myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Sir, I am ready to attend you any where.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: And for me, Mr. Friendly, I am now indifferent whither I go.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, Madam, all, I hope, will be clear'd up.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Oh, thou villain?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.STAGE: [Following her, shakes his fist at her.]
SP.P: a—h!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Mrs. Friendly and Emily sitting. Wellford leaning on the back of Emily's chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: WELL, but child, now that the Captain is convinced that his suspicions were foolish, and groundless, and idle, and ridiculous, and every thing; you ought to forgive him, and make up your quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: No, Madam, what I have declared, was but in justice to my own character; for the rest, I am little solicitous to satisfy a man, capable first of suspecting, and then of accusing me, as he has done.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Very true, my dear, capable of suspecting and accusing; but jealousy you know is of all things—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Blind, blind and infatuated!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: To think I cou'd favour such a mean impostor! a cheat even to his very name!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Ay, a paltry subaltern fellow! that was broke for cowardice! after the Captain, as he tells me, had saved him from being killed by another officer.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I acknowledge my fault with all its aggravations; yet I thought my penitence, my grief, for having so justly provoked this lady's resentment, might have attoned for an offence, which nothing but the strongest love cou'd have oc∣casion'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I can't think what Sharply—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, Madam! don't name a wretch any more, tht has occasioned so much mischief!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Bless me, Captain! don't be so sudden! I de∣clare you startle one in a manner!—I say, I wonder what can keep Sharply and Rose so long with Mr. Friendly! they have been lock'd up now almost—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You'll soon know, Madam. Here is Mr. Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Lord! Mr. Friendly, what have you been about all this while?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Sharply has told me something that has surprized me exceedingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Ay! what can it be? but pray, my dear, first tell me, were the candles li't in the drawing room as you came by? for I expect company.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Psha;—I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: What has he told you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why, nothing less than that Sir John—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Any body's question will be answered before mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I wish your drawing room and your company were—Sir John is married!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Married!

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: To whom, in the name of wonder?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Now don't tell him, Mr. Friendly, but let me guess; you know I have an excellent guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Prithee, my dear, give me leave;—why to that com∣pound of mischief and wickedness, Mrs. Etherdown.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: You amaze me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: It does not amaze me in the least now; I knew it wou'd come to that as well as if—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Sure, Sir, this must be an invention of Sharply's?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Don't you remember, my dear, I told you about a month ago, when you and I were talking of Sir John; don't you remember I said, says I—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Ay, ay, I remember your prophesy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Now you see—just the same way I foretold Mr. Testy's marriage with the widow; and Mrs. Lofty's with—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, good wife! give others leave to speak as well as yourself.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Pray, Captain, do I hinder him? I declare one would imagine that—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Dear Madam, let me ask Mr. Friendly a question or two.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P:
There now again, as if I stopp'd you I wou'd not one think that I kept all the discourse to myself? and
now, pray Mr. Wellford, all the while we were at piquet after dinner, did I say a syllable but what was absolutely ne∣cessary, except two or three times that I ask'd you, What you were thinking of? And you said, Of your cards; and I said—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: There's no bearing this; come with me into my study, Wellford; her tongue's wound up for an hour, and she must let it run down.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: The ladies are come, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I'll wait on them.—A fine character I should get indeed, if people were to take Mr. Friendly's word!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: How long does that fellow say, Sir John has been married?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Above a year, he tells me; and if it be true, the son he has by Mrs. Etherdown is legitimate, and Emily's hopes are cut off at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I am glad of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: How, Sir! that I'm not worth a shilling.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: No, Madam; but that I can now convince all the world, I love you for your own sake only. You, I hope, wanted no such proof of the sincerity of my affection. Oh! Friendly! I have offended, too justly provoked my Emily's resentment! persuade her to forgive my fault, and let me call her mine.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What say you, Madam? This generosity deserves a kind return; and if Sir John consents—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Hold, Sir! I own I have pride—perhaps too much; and cannot bear to lay myself under obligations, where I once hoped to have the power of conferring them.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: But, Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Excuse me, Mr. Friendly: Let me only beg the pro∣tection of your roof till my uncle's return: I dare say, when he hears how cruelly I have been treated, he will provide for me somewhere: Perhaps I may trouble you but for a night or two.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P:
And whither will you then go? By heaven! you shall never be at the mercy of those abandoned wretches, while I have life or power to succour you.—Oh! Emily, this is not the return I expected from your tenderness! To whom ought you to fly for shelter, but to the man that
loves you with such an honest and disinterested passion as I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: No, Wellford, no; you ought to know me better. The woman whom you have debased by your mean suspi∣cions, will not, on such terms, condescend to be your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: A noble girl, by my soul! 'twere pity you should lose her.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Lose her! I'd lose my life as soon. Dear Friendly, if you wou'd preserve that, do you and your wife use all your influence on her. That pride too, which would de∣form another woman, makes her still more beautiful.—What is fortune in comparison with such a mind?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why, all this is very fine, I grant you; but the loss of a good estate is a damned baulk notwithstanding, Well∣ford.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: By all that's good, Friendly, I despise it; let me but possess my Emily, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: You'll live in a cottage on love—determined like a true Arcadian swain; but it won't do in this part of the world, let me tell you, boy. But to be serious; what Sharply has told me, he has no other authority for, than Mrs. Etherdown's own word; though he adds, that Sir John, on account of this child's birth, means directly to own his marriage. However, I'll suspend my belief till I am better inform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: But have you let Sharply escape? I had forgot to inquire after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Oh! I have made him my own. I got him to draw up in writing a full account of Mrs. Etherdown's scheme con∣certed with him against Emily; together with some other curious anecdotes, to which Rose and he are privy: Which notable confession I have made them both sign.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: And what use do you purpose to make of it? 'Tis of little consequence now, methinks, to separate Sir John and his precious bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I have a design in my head to bring that worthless puppy, if possible, to a sense of his folly. I cannot now explain the whole of my plan to you, for I mean to go im∣mediately to Sir John's, who they tell me is expected home every minute; but Emily shall not know this, as I wish for your sake to detain her a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I have but little hopes, for I know the firmness of her temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, come, courage, man; you know you have a friend within; I'll venture to bring you to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Do what you will with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Have done, have done, wench, with your silly re∣proaches; Emily will be kind to you, tho' in regard to your motive, she is but little obliged to you for her fancied deliver∣ance.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Fancied!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Yes, fancied, ye mischievous baggage! Why, to what end do you imagine I ran away with that girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: To what end, traitor! Why did you carry her to that house? Answer me that, varlet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Thou art a poor shallow-pated gipsey; very unsit to share the counsels of the wise; but for once I'll inform you. I meant first to be well paid for my trouble, then to discover the whole secret (that trifling circumstance excepted) to Friendly, and fairly to deliver Emily into his hands, ma∣king a merit of my own great in tegrity;—and lastly, I meant (that I own I did) to rumple the young baggage a little, partly out of spite, and to shew my power, which would have enhanced the worth of her deliverance.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: And you did so, I warrant, Mr Impudence?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Why no, faith, I don't know how that happened; these honest girls have a damn'd impertinent way of keeping a man in awe; besides, when I heard that hot-headed fellow Wellford was her lover, I confess it did damp my courage a little—But no matter, your curst intermeddling has un∣done my whole plan, and what would have appeared an act of virtue, seems now the result only of fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: And how was I to know all this? I am sure, only I thought you were going to leave me, I had as soon have been burnt—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Well, well, I'm not now at leisure to hear your excuses. I suppose Sir John has sworn a thousand oaths by this time, at my being out of the way; 'tis well if you have not been missed too.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: If I should, I have an excuse ready.—Well, Mr. Sharply, sha'nt we be friends again?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Not now, you puppy, 'twould take up too much time; hereafter perhaps I may take you into favour.—But get you to your mistress; I must change my clothes, and then go to Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Marry, hang you! I believe that will be your fate at last.—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: A Chamber. A Table with Bottles and Glasses. Mrs. Ether∣down sitting at it. Sir John half nodding in an elbow Chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I am so tired I can hardly keep myself awake. No news of this blockhead Sharply yet?—Come, why don't you take your glass?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: La! Sir John, you know I hate it of all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What then, you abstemious jackanapes; one glass to welcome me home:—it won't poison you, will it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, as you say, Sir John; I can't refuse that, tho' it shou'd poison me.
SP.STAGE: [She fills a little drop. He nods again; and she fills a bumper and drinks.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Take off your glass, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I vow I can't touch any more, Sir John; it gives one such a flushing in one's face, when one isn't us'd to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, this comes of your drinking water; nothing but water will go down forsooth:—why it is enough to kill you, you fool.—I am as sleepy as if I had taken opium.
SP.STAGE: [He nods again, and Sharply peeps in at the door and creeps over.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: What, fast!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Hush—what has kept you so long?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Is t'other hundred ready? We are secure I war∣rant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John
SP.P: Secure! what are you secure of? Ha! Sharply, is it you? Shake hands, you whelp.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: A—h, Sir John, did you pretend to be asleep! you are so full of tricks!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Where have you been all this while? What the d—l has your blund'ring head been about now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Been! why, I have been and dun'd every tenant you have in London, from top to bottom, this good day; and if I can get a cross from them, I wish I may never be worth one. I have been out since morning: my sister there can tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: It's true, indeed, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What were you saying about being secure?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Oh!—ay, we are secure enough for that matter. I was saying I had got security from that scurvy fellow there, that owes you a hundred pound. He that keeps the great inn there in what-de-call-um—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: In Holborn! ay, that's a sad dog! a sad dog! must turn him out:—But you are such a poor, soft, easy, quiet mungrel, let them but warm your heart with a bowl of punch, and make a poor mouth, and call you your ho∣nour, they may keep me out of my rent till dooms-day for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, as you say, Sir John, he little knows the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I'll turn you off, by my soul, Sharply, if you don't learn to know the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: I strive.—Ask my sister else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Strive! poor devil; you do your best, I believe. Come, I'm glad your come in; can't drink by myself;—and Madam here, won't touch a drop.—Sit down there.—Do you know that Emily is run away?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Miss Emily, Sir! our Miss Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, our Miss Emily, Sir.—How Sharply gapes at the news?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: No wonder, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Its only one of your jokes, may be, Sir John: you are such a joker! But I don't believe every thing you say for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Its too true, as Sir John says.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I have found out the whole plot, tho', you must know; and to-morrow I intend so to work Friendly about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Mr. Friendly! ay,—to be sure, he is a knowing man, and can give fine advice when a body's in trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Confound your loggerhead! do you think I want advice, or would take advice, and from him? Why, he is the whole contriver of the thing, man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Who! Mr. Friendly, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Yes: Mr. Friendly! as Sir John says.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Lord! I'd never ha' thought that of him!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You'd never ha' thought! Why, you numscull, how the plague shou'd you think, that mind nothing but dunning of tenants, and then excusing them their rent? A good joke, i'faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: That's true, indeed, Sir John; he knows no∣thing, poor soul, but the keeping his own books.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And a miracle 'tis to me, that he can do even that! Take him out of his figures, and my coach dog has more sagacity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! Well, well, I wou'd not give my figures for all your wit:—now, Sir John, there's for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: True! there you're right, Sharply. Every man has his talent.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv. Mr.
SP.P: Friendly's come to wait on you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What the plague can Friendly want with me now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: To try how the land lies, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: He'll find himself cursedly bit.—I think, I am a match for Friendly. Give me but a clue, and let me alone to unwind a piece of knavery.—Get you both into the next room. Desire Mr. Friendly to walk in. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: I wou'd not stand in Mr. Friendly's shos, no, by the sun and moon, not for all the money in his pocket.—You'll work him, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, Sir John, now's your time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Yes, yes: I think I am a match for Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Your servant, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: How do you do, Sir John? I heard, by accident, you were arrived, and just call'd in as I pass'd by.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh, I thank you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: You seem out of humour, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Perhaps I really am so, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I am sorry you have any occasion; but you need not shew it to your friends. Prithee, what has ruffled you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Nothing worth ruffling my temper, or any man's temper; women will be women.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Something about Mrs. Etherdown, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No, Sir, it is not; you are always supposing in the wrong place.—There's my niece—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Run away—that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Run away! impossible! with whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: How the d—l should I know? with a man, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: It can't be! When did she go? Have you sent to enquire after her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ounds! what a catechising is here! I don't know when she went, nor where to look for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I presume she'll come back again!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, when she's ready for the magdalen-house, I suppose she may.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Fy, fy, Sir John! how can you talk with so much levity of so good a girl, and so near a relation?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Prithee, Friendly, none of your sanctified airs. A good girl! and a near relation! I warrant you'd have me be mighty anxious about her virtue now, and try to recover her, for fear she shou'd be ruin'd, as you call it. Not I, by the mass! if the wench has a mind to take her fling, e'en let her, for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: But have you no regard for—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
The Honour of my family, I hope you are going to say—uph, uph, uph—Yes, I'll tell you how far I
regard it: as I shou'd not chuse to have my estate squan∣dered away upon beggarly rascals, with handsome faces, (the use to which, I suppose, my hopeful niece wou'd apply it) this frolic of her's has determined me—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: To what?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: To what goes plaguely against my stomach; but necessity—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I'd as lieve be a slave in the gallies; but since the young hussy has provoked me to it, I am resolved—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: On what, prithee?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: To marry, Sir, if you must know.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: The Duce you will! you'd as soon hang yourself!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
