SP.P: Ay, ay, that's true; I do hate the thoughts of it most cn—sumedly, you know I do; but when a man's ill us'd in his own family—and to tell you the truth, Friendly, I don't find myself so young as I was some years ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: No! that's strange!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And faith, I begin to think it's time to settle, and live a little honestly; a man can't hold out always, to drive such a carcer. I have been a sad dog, that's the truth on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Oh, you intend to mend then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No, hang it, I don't say that neither; I don't know whether I can mend or not;—what's bred in the bone, you know—the old leaven, I'm afraid; but a man may try.—Come, Friendly, let me have a little of thy advice. I have a mind to marry, as I told you; what sort of a wo∣man, now, do you think wou'd suit me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why, if you are actually resolved—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Peremptorily.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: In the first place then, I wou'd not have you marry one that's over young.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Right—not a giddy girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: In the next place, one whom you think doesn't mar∣ry you merely for the sake of your fortune; but a woman who can have some regard for your person.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ah▪ good!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: One of a mild and gentle temper, who can bear with all your odd humours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Excellent!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: One who wou'd be prudent in the management of your family, and not given to expensive pleasures.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oraculous! [Aside. Bab's the very thing.] Well, and what more?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Nay, I think that's enough, you need not desire money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Give me your hand. [Aside. Bab to a tittle; she's not worth a groat.] Egad, Friendly, you never talked so sensibly in your life; and now, who do you think an∣swers this description in every point?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Nay, I can't tell; I suppose there are women enough to be found who do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Suppose I were to name one: what think you of Bab?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Mrs. Etherdown! marry Mrs. Etherdown!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What! you don't approve of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I do not, indeed, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Aside. Oh! I thought so.] But why not? I always intended to marry her, when I grew weary of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: That's a strange paradox.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Not at all; for may be, in a cross fit, I might turn her off; and then I know I shou'd repent it, I am so used to her little coaxing ways.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why, do you know the consequence of marrying a kept mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What! if I keep her myself, man?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: That makes very little difference, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: No! believe me, a woman who has been used to con∣sider a man as a kind of property, of whom she is to make the most, while his inclination to her lasts, will not easily be brought to think, that there is but one common interest be∣tween them, as man and wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ah! she won't?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Nor can she who has been accustomed to caresses, and flattery and stuff, as a mistress, descend to the meek, the tender, the complying duties of a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Indeed! [Aside. How I'll surprize him just now.] Why, Bab has always been the most obliging, submissive creature in the world to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: She finds it her interest to be so, but if once she were sure of you, she'd change her note.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You don't tell me so!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Take my word for it, Sir John, if you were to marry that woman, you'd repent it before a week were at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! ha! poor Friendly! thou art, ge∣nerally speaking damnably out of thy judgment; but were never more so in thy life than now! For you must know:—ha! ha! ha! excuse my laughing at you, you must know, that I have been married to her above two and fifty weeks, and have never repented of it yet. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Oh, Sir John—enjoy your laugh; but that joke won't take.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John
SP.P: Oh—the devil! what, because I am a facetious puppy, and now and then a little sarcastical, do you think I am never serious?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I understand you, Sir John;—you want to trick your niece out of her inheritance; and Mrs. Etherdown and you have entered into a confederacy to say you are married.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ah! do you begin to feel?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Who do you think will take your word?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I'm an unlucky dog in point of character, that I own;—but I can prove this, honest Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I defy you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ah! does it sting? can name the parson and the witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: You may name a parson that has been transported, and a witness, may be, that has been hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What do you think of my little toping curate, of Woodall Green; is he transported? and our old friend in equity, Tom Shifter, is he hang'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Were they your operators?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ask them.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! Who's the fool now, Friendly?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: 'Tis even so then—well, peace be with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Poor devil! how he's mortified! don't go, man.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What am I to stay for?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I want a little more of your advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Confound you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I wish you joy of your heiress, Friendly!—Ha! ha! a turbulent booby! I'll go and tell Bab tho'.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV3.STAGE: Sharply and Mrs. Etherdown enter as he goes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! are you there! come in.—He's gone.—E'gad I have given it to him!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I cou'd hear you, Sir John, laughing at him as he went out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But the best joke of all is, he pretends not to believe what I told him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: And here's this wiseacre does n't believe it nei∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: No, nor wont unless Sir John says it; ay, and swear to it too, that's more, for all you think me so easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And why not, Sharply? come, let's have your wise reasons.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Sir John, now mind me; only mind what I am going to say—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Observe his important face.—Now, for a weighty sentence of sound argument! out with it, Sharply.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Sir John, I have known you early and late; and tho' I am one that don't very well comprehend—that is, I am not very capable—I mean, I can't so very well express—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha! ha! poor Sharply! ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: There it is now, you always dash one in the middle of an argument; and because you have more learning, and can talk like a satyr, a body must not speak plain sense be∣fore you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Call it a satyrist the next time, Sharply.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: You may call it what you please; but reason is reason, and truth is truth, and so I don't believe a word of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Fact tho', for all that, Sharply.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: My sister Lady Woodall! O—h!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: The dog's proud of it, you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: My dear Sir John! you are so good!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Good! by all the flesh of my back, I wou'd not be such a sinner! no, not for all his land! Take that now, Sir John:—you find I can be smart when I please. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! scurrilous varlet;—but you are right, Sharply, I have done such things in my time! Ha! ha! ha! did I ever show you my list? no, I believe not; hang it, I never loved boasting—there were not above nine of them that I did not turn off next day tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Nine! I don't know what nine you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Only of the girls that I have had; none of them behaved like my old girl here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: She's a sensible woman to be sure, for all she's my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No, no, Sharply, no; not much of that neither: But she is docile; a teachable wench enough; and with a little of my training we do pretty well: e'nt it so, Bab?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, as you say Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Come, here's your health. I can't but think of that booby, Friendly, how he must be gall'd! and his meddling fool of a wife, I wish she would cuckold him, that I might laugh at him about her virtue.—Here's his health tho', I have known him these twenty years.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: I'd speak with you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Where now, Bab?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Only to give some orders to Rose, Sir John.
SP.STAGE: [She makes signs of drinking to Sharply, and Exit.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Married!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Faith, Sharply, I began to think it high time to wipe off the score.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: And my sister Lady Woodall!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Confound you, leave off your exclamations, and put the bottle about.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: And all unknown to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: The dog's beginning to get drunk! and I shall be overwhelm'd with a deluge or folly and impertinence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: And I'll warrant, you have settled the Lord knows what upon her!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What's that to you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P:
Sir John, now mind what I say. You know, I am very apt to give a little good advice now and then, and
tho' you rail at me so, I can't for the blood of me keep it.—Now, I wou'd not have settled sixpence on her, were I you, for all she's my sister. I'd know how to manage a wife, I warrant: I am sharp enough in some things. She's as proud as Lucifer, tho' she's my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: That's a lie;—if she has any thing good, 'tis her humility and meekness, buzzard!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: And an extravagant woman, tho' I say it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Another lie!—if she has any virtue, 'tis her good oeconomy.—I'd trust her with all I'm worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: By the sun that shines then, so would not I, nor e'er a woman that ever wore a head; I have a little judgment too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Judgment! you judgment!

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Sir John, listen to me now, and let me advise you—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: By my soul, I'll break your head, if you begin to advise, Sharply.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: By this good day, I never was in such a humour for giving advice in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You are ever so when you are drunk, you dog; tho' you can't speak a sentence of common sense when you are sober.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Then 'tis my duty never to be sober; for I find myself at this minute as wise as any oracle that ever was born, and therefore my advice is pro and con—No settlement.—Mark what the oracle says.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I do, I do; and to shew what prodigious influ∣ence your sage counsel has on me, I intend—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! I knew you'd come about; you find I have judgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Tho' I never thought of doing it before, I shall settle a hundred a-year upon her, for all she's your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: What, after all my arguments against it! By this hand of mine then, I'll have nothing to say to it. Mr. Friendly wou'd no more do such a thing than he'd eat fire. Sir John, I say thirty pounds a-year; observe me now; and that only during pleasure, do you mind?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Two hundred a-year, by the Lord! and that settled irrevocably, since you provoke me to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Mercy upon me! Well, don't be too hasty now, Sir John, in this affair, but think a few days, and consult—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Burn you! whom should I consult?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Mr. Frie—no,—not Mr. Friendly, I don't mean him—but argue, and think, and reason with your∣self—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You know I always take your advice, and therefore—it shall be done directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: What, not to night, Sir John; you are not be∣witch'd sure.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Sharply—depart in a whole skin, and take a walk to Mr. Bustle's, you'll find him in his chambers at this hour.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Won't next week do as well, Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Utter one word more, and I break every bone in your body. The thing shall be done now, immediately, this identical night, and I'll surprise my Lady Woodall with it to-morrow. I'll write a line to my lawyer, and you shall carry it, to shew you of what importance you are.—So come to me in half-an-hour; in the mean while, go and sleep your∣self sober, most oraculous Sharply.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha! thou incorrigible coxcomb! thou empty, vain, bragging sot! whose greatest boast is the being a rascal, whilst in reality your greatest vice is being a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I Wish Mr. Friendly were returned, tho' I expect nothing but a confirmation of Sir John's marriage;—but any thing is better than suspense.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I declare and vow, Captain, I am as restless, and as unsettled, and as perturbed, as I may say, on poor Emi∣ly's account; but Mr. Friendly will come at the truth, de∣pend upon it he will.—I remember just such an affair once, it was the most dark intricate business, and so tedious;—I'll tell you the whole story—You must know—

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Oh! thank my stars, here's Friendly come to relieve me]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I'll tell you another time, Captain—Well, my dear, what news?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: 'Tis even as Sir John said; he is actually married. I have found out the person who was present.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: And he own'd it to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: He scrupled at first, but finding I was let into the se∣cret, he confirmed every thing that Sir John told me. I am heartily sorry for it for Emily's sake. Have you seen her this morning, Wellford?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Not yet;—but I purpose presently going to take my leave of her; for I am determined to set out this night in order to join my regiment;—and if nothing happens to change my fortune, why then—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What then, man, thou wilt not hang thyself on a wil∣low!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Heaven forbid! you have more grace than to do so, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I hope so too, Madam; but I shall be but little so∣licitous to preserve a life, that without her will be a bur∣den.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I declare and protest I am so grieved for you I am ready to cry perfectly;—but who knows what may hap∣pen? Emily may still change her mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Oh! I have not the least expectation of that; one thing however let me request of you both before I go.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What is it, Wellford? you know you may command us.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: That you will take Emily under your protection. To what must she be exposed in such a world as this? young and beautiful as she is—an orphan—without fortune—Let me not have the grief to add, without friends too.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: You need not doubt my tenderness for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Will you, my dear Mrs. Friendly, be a mother to my Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Will I! my own daughter shall not be more welcome to me, I assure you, Mr. Wellford.—I protest I am so troubled; I never was more troubled in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I beg pardon for thus distressing you.—We'll talk no more on the subject; the few hours I have to stay ought not to be spent in fruitless vexation.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: A few hours sometimes produces strange revolutions, especially in a woman's mind—Emily's may alter.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Oh! you don't know her as well as I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Well, I'll not oppose you, only beg for the pre∣sent you'll clear up your brow a little. I have a mind to have some mirth with Sir John this morning, which shall however only be a prelude to a more serious scene. I shall go to him presently, and pretending not to believe a syllable in regard to his marriage, I will, by way of prevention, lay open all Mrs. Etherdown's conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: This may entertain you, Friendly; but what is it to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I wish, my dear, it was consistent for me to go with you, that I might help you to talk to him properly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Oh! you shall have an opportunity: I find he is pos∣sessed with a belief that Emily has been inveigled away thro' mine and my wife's means.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Our means, my dear? Why, can he suppose—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Ay; but when he finds that his own dear Bab is at the bottom of it, I'll answer for it, that my Lady Woodall will be turn'd off with disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: What does that signify now? She has done all the mischief she could already.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: For my part, I think it will be doing an act of charity to rid Sir John of such a notorious body.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: No doubt, Madam, it is a christian office to part a man and his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: From such a wife I think it is, Mr. Wellford.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Right, my dear, Wellford is out of humour, and wou'd pervert our meaning.—Leave the management of the business to me; I think I shall entertain you.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I fancy not; but take your own way.—You'll excuse me; I must go and give orders about my journey, and then I'll come, and bid Emily adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Perhaps you don't go, Wellford.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Certainly, Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Poor man! I vow I pity him.—If you are going to Sir John's, my dear, I'll step up stairs to Emily.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Ay; go and comfort the sweet girl.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Changes to Sir John's. Mrs. Etherdown at her Toilt, Rose attending.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: A penurious wretch! two hundred a year, and his estate as many thousand!

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: You may thank your stars you have got so much, Madam.—I reckon Mrs. Friendly has blazed your mar∣riage all over the town, for here have been I don't know how many people with their bills this morning already.—Here's a comfortable breakfast for him.
SP.STAGE: [Rose takes out a parcel of papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: They are sent in by my own direction, lay them down there. I now only want to provoke him to part with me, but it shall be his own act and deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Ay, for then, I suppose, he must give you a separate maintenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Right; for if you are faithful, nothing can be proved against me; and then you and I, Rose, will live to∣gether, and so enjoy ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Ay, that will be charming.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Did you order the jeweller to call?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: I did, Ma'am; he will be here presently.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir John, speaking as he comes in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Bab, Bab, my Bab!—What, what, what have we got here? What's all this bedizzening for? Patch'd! and painted too, I believe, by my soul!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Sir John, you will oblige me, if for the future you will knock at the door before you come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Hey! knock at the door! it was not that you said, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: It is not manners to come so abruptly into a la∣dy's dressing-room; 'tis not indeed, Sir John. And let me beseech you not to be so vulgarly familiar.—Lady Woodall hereafter, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Rose, can you tell what ails your mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: There's nothing ails my lady, that I know of, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No! Why but, Bab?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Bab, again! In two words, Sir John, I expect to be treated with a little more ceremony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Hey day, mad, by my soul! fit for Bedlam! This comes of my owning her! I must take her down a peg or so.—Get you out of the room.—
I gave you a paper this morning; a little parchment, you know; a settlement on you, Bab. [I'll take it from her, by the Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Well, Sir! what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why, there was a mistake committed in the drawing of it up; let me have it again, that I may get it rec∣tify'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I have n't it about me, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Here's Mr. Brilliant. Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Bid him come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Mr. Brilliant! who the d—l's he?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: My lady's jeweller, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: My lady's jeweller, quotha?—We'l, I'll treat you with a ring, since you put me in mind of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Servant, Mr. Brilliant—What have got there?

SP.SPEAKER: Jew.
SP.P: I made bold to bring your ladyship a few things, that I fancy will please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Let's see.

SP.SPEAKER: Jew.
SP.P: Here's a pair of ear-rings will come cheap; I can let your ladyship have them for two hundred and eighty pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Baubles! How do you like, Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: 'Pshaw!—If you have got ever a neat diamond hoop, of about nine or ten guineas, my wife may be a pur∣chaser.

SP.SPEAKER: Jew.
SP.P: None so low as that, Sir; I have from fifteen to twenty—will your ladyship please to look at these?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No, no; you have nothing here that we want.

SP.SPEAKER: Jew.
SP.P: I have brought a bill, according to your orders, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Give it to Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I have no occasion for it, Sir; I suppose I can furnish myself at any other shop as well as at yours.
SP.STAGE: [Throws down the bill, without looking at it.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: That's no reason you shou'd not pay him, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Pay him! for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: A few trifles that I have had of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jew.
SP.P: You'll find my charges very reasonable, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Well, well, Sir, you may carry your trinkets away.

SP.SPEAKER: Jew.
SP.P: If Sir John does n't like the jewels, madam, I shall be very ready to take them again, with some allowance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Sir, I shall keep them—and Sir John will pay you for them another time—Next week you shall have your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Jew.
SP.P: It's very well, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: So Bab! egad, this was a good bold push—and you really thought I was to be drawn in to buy you some of these gym-cracks!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: No, no; I know you too well for that; but I think you ought to be ashamed not to pay your honest debts.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Debts!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, there are all the people's bills.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Bills!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: And vastly reasonable they are, in my mind—I don't suppose the whole [He examines them.] amounts to above fifteen hundred pound—You find I have not been extravagant, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why, what!—you don't mean, I suppose, that these are debts!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Real debts—contracted by me your lawful wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And that I am to pay them! you don't mean that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Undoubtedly—who else shou'd pay a woman's debts, but her husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And I am your husband, and you are my wife; and all these are real, actual debts, you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: All reality, substantial truth, as you will find to your cost—Ha, ha, ha! the sarce is at an end between us; and you will find me quite a different creature from what you supposed, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why—why—why—what the devil are you? a woman or a fiend?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! a woman, a woman of spirit, a woman of fashion, a woman of pleasure, expence, profusion, luxury! what do you think of me now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why, you are an imp of hell, I believe; where's your sawcer eyes, and your cloven feet—and, and, and, and—your horns, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Oh! I leave them for you, my dear Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Dear! damnable!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Why, do you fancy I could ever have any re∣gard for such a thing as you are?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Curse me, but I have a good mind to—to—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: To beat me, I hope: ha, ha, ha! do, at your peril! Who is it that you threaten with your anger? Do you take me for the tame fool I have appeared all this while? And do you fancy I'll submit to your absurd humours, mere∣ly for a maintenance? No, no, Sir; let me tell you, I shall enter upon a new system; I must have my separate purse, se∣parate chariot, separate bed, my morning concerts, routs, visiting days—and if you expect I should live with you—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Live with me! fire and sulphur! I'd as soon—I'll lock you up in a dungeon—feed you on bread and wa∣ter—bastinado you!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Starve you—make you lie on straw—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I despise your menaces: I am your wife, ac∣knowledged in the face of the world; and I'll make you know it too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I'll turn you out of my doors; expose you, brand you! confound me if I don't.—And that scoundrel Sharp∣ly, I'll kick him out of my house too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Impotent threatening! we both laugh at you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I'll make you an example to all the—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv. Mr.
SP.P: Friendly, Sir, is come to wait on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I won't see him, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: He's coming up, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You dog, how dare you let him in?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Good-day to you, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: So, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why so gruff, Sir John? What's the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Poh!—nothing at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Nothing at all! that can't be; you have too much sense and too much temper to be out of humour at nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: 'Pshaw—it is next to nothing—only a little foolish debate here, between Madam and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: A debate between you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
Ay, she has been playing the wag a little with
me this morning, that's all.—What sort of weather is it abroad, Friendly?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Nay, Sir John, I am afraid there's more in this; you don't use to wear so angry a brow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: 'Pshaw—I tell you I am not in the least angry:—will you drink a dish of chocolate, Friendly?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Not any, Sir John.—And you, Madam, seem extremely ruffled.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Mr. Friendly, I'll appeal to you, whether Sir John uses me well: he has refused to pay a debt for me this morning, and has been so peevish about it!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Oh fy, Sir John! there I must take your lady's part; so prudent a woman as Lady Woodall! such an oeco∣nomist! 'tis but a trifle, I'll lay my life now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: But seven hundred pound, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Seven hundred devils!—don't believe her a word she says, man.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Seven hundred pound! that's a good round sum! but I suppose my lady has made some pretty little purchase now, for your use; and you are so testy because you did not do it yourself—Come, own, is not that the case now?—What is it, Madam? a bit of land in the country? or a house in town?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Poh!—split your enquiries—Why, there's not a syllable of truth in the thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Nay, Sir John, you can't deny that you refused the man payment; the jewels, I am sure, are cheap of the money; and if I am not to appear like other people of my rank, I might as well be Mrs. Etherdown still as lady Woodall.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Oh! what it was for trinkets then? humph; to be sure, Sir John, you ought to pay your wife's debts; and in my opinion—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Rot your opinion, Sir! keep it to yourself—'s curse, you are so inquisitive, and so troublesome, one wou'd take you for your wife that had got into breeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Lud! Sir John, how can you be so ill bred? you have not the least idea of good manners:—You can't imagine, how rude he was to me just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Rude to your lady! Oh monstrous! and to such a meek woman too!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: S'death, Sir, I'll be angry when I please; and reconciled when I please; without asking your leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, come, if my lady has offended you, she'll ask your pardon; she's all submission and obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I ask his pardon! if he had any shame in him, he wou'd down on his knees to ask mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: And she has such little coaxing ways, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: This is damn'd hard, that a man must be be∣sieged with such impertinence in his own house; prithee, Friendly, mind your own affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, Sir John, all jesting apart; I will now do the office of a friend by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Sir, I want none of your offices.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Look ye, Sir John, as I did not think you wou'd have persisted in this ridiculous pretence of your being mar∣ried, I wou'd not, last night, add to the vexation of your niece's being stolen from you, the knowledge of this vile wo∣man's conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: You are an officious fellow, Sir; and if this be your business, I desire you will leave my house directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Your house!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Yes, my house, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Madam, Madam! this affair is growing too serious:—I know Sir John is not married to you; we don't take him for such a fool neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Sir, I shall call a servant to shew you the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I shou'd not wish to expose you, bad as you are, if I were not afraid, that my friend's utter disgrace wou'd be the consequence of his suffering you to pass for his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Eth.
SP.P: Are not you ashamed, Sir John, to stand by, and listen to his scurrility?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: E'gad, I think you seem to be a match for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Sir John, this woman, I speak it before her face, has betray'd and deceiv'd you in every article.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: I scorn all that your malice can invent.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: But I can prove it, Madam: nay, what's more, that it was by your contrivance Emily was spirited away by that rascal Sharply.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! Emily spirited away by Sharply!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Yes, Sir John: that scoundrel, that vile tool, that abettor in all her iniquity, has conveyed your niece away, and married her by this time, for ought I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! much good may do him with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What, in the name of Beelzebub, is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: 'Tis all as I tell you, Sir John; this precious hypocrite here, you see, doesn't deny it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Sir John, you are the greatest poltroon in Europe, if you don't fight him for abusing your wife thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Wife! the vengeance! I don't believe you are my wife, if you go to that;—I▪ I never was married—get out of my house this minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay, deny me, if you dare:—I am Lady Woodall in spite of you, all the town knows it now.—Thanks to your wife, the publick cryer cou'd not have pro∣claimed it more effectually.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, courage, Sir John; don't let the termagant frighten you, speak boldly and say at once, she is not your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Ay do, encourage him to expose himself, ho∣nourable, honest Mr. Friendly!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: O—nz! I believe she is not my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Believe! are not you certain of it, Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I wish I was;—but I am not certain, there's the curse of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: What! married to such a creature as this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Yes—and this creature will force you, ay, you Sir, in spite of your turbulence, to the full proof of what he has acknowledged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Get you out of my doors, thou fiend!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Eth.
SP.P: Oh! it is mighty well, Sir!—remember you turn me out of your doors! yes, I will quit your house, and leave you to the scorn and laughter of mankind. When next you hear from me, it shall be with an authority that neither you nor your friend there, that meddling, cynical, informing coxcomb shall dare to dispute; and so, with the utmost con∣tempt, I turn my back upon you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Is this really so, Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Really so, Sir John! what the d—l signifies your coming with your queries now? cou'd n't you have told me this before?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Before what? don't you say, you have been married above this twelvemonth?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Death and fire, Sir! it is enough to distract a man to hear such things—That woman is turned into a fury, I think—It's all magic and witchcraft.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I am very sorry, Sir John—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Burn your sorrow, Sir, keep it to yourself—Unfaithful to me!—Friendly, this is damn'd odd of you to say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: True, believe me, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And Emily ran away with by Sharply!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Fact—and by your wife's contrivance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh the infernal sorceress!—but it can't be, man! the thing's impossible! the fellow's almost an idiot!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Oh, you are as much deceived in that as in the rest—I tell you, he has own'd it all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: A dog! but I have one comfort left, the rascal's bit in his hopes; he thought Emily was to be my heir—I have a son, tho' his mother may be a—But I don't believe a word you say, Friendly—Do now, own that it's all a con∣founded lye of your own inventing; do, dear Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I wish it were for your sake; but it's all too true, Sir John; and what is still worse, Sharply will possess your estate in spite of you. That boy which has been palm'd upon you for your own, is not even your wife's; but some brat brought in on purpose to induce you to own your marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Death, Sir! do you take me for a stock, or an idiot! that you attempt to make me swallow such impos∣sibilities?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Read this paper, Sir John—'Tis Sharply's full con∣fession of the whole plot—Rose, who was her mistress's agent in the conveyance of the child, (tho' she herself was ignorant of the design) in her days of fondness for Sharply let him into the cheat—You will find the whole account there, when you are calm enough to peruse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And the villain knowing this, has married Emily!—I'll have him hang'd—as sure as fate he swings for this—That's a comfort—He has stolen an heiress, know∣ing her to be such.—And that wicked she imp—I'll be divorc'd from her.—You can prove her an adultress, you say?—You shall prove it, and I'll be divorc'd—that's another comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: There, I'm afraid, Sir John, we shall find a difficulty; for, tho' we have the strongest presumptive proof in the world against her, yet the law requires more in those cases.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Sir, it shall have all, and more than it requires.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: There is not the least doubt of your being (I am sorry to say) a cuckold, Sir John; yet the crime can't be proved against your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John
SP.P: Furies, Sir! how dare you call me a cuckold? If any thing would make me fight you—You are a barbarous unworthy fellow, so you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why is not your wife—?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Wife! Uph—uph—Oh! Friendly, that word is worse than ten thousand daggers.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Now, Sir John, you see the consequence of your fool∣ish as well as criminal affectation, of wanting to pass for a worse man than you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: The fiends!—the vipers!—the monsters!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Do you think that a woman who could submit to live with you, under the infamous imputation of being kept, could have any principles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Hell-hounds! robbers! and murderers!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Or that a low rascal, like Sharply, the mean flatterer of your follies, and the real practiser of your imaginary vices, whose sole business in your family was to prey on your fortune, and make a jest of your person, was to be bound by any ties of gratitude?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Scorpions! serpents! furies!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Or could you expect that an inexperienced young crea∣ture like Emily could be trusted in the house with two such wretches as I have described, and not be undone?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! Friendly, Friendly, Friendly!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Do you see your folly?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: My folly! my purgatory! my hell! Don't let your wife come near me, nor Sharply, nor Emily, nor my own everlasting torment—I'll cut my own throat—My estate shall be forfeited—I'd be burnt at a stake, rather than let them have it!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Will you at last submit to be advised by me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What can advice do now? Am not I married to a strumpet?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Turn her off.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Suppose I do, I can't marry again, can't hope for an heir, and my estate will go to a scoundrel, that has ruined my poor niece.—Oh! Friendly, I am punished for the sins of my youth!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir John, I pity you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
S'death! have I lived to be pitied too!—Sir, you sha'nt pity me; I wo'nt be pitied by e'er a man alive.—And now I am recovered from my surprise, you shall see the
justice I will do myself on that crocodile and her brother.—Who's there!
Bid your mistress come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Her brother! Why Sharply's no more her brother than he is mine; he has acknowledged that he was only a creature of her's entertained under that notion to impose on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Mercy on me! mercy on me!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, my lady is just gone out, and said she should not return.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What's to be done now, Friendly?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why now, Sir John, I think we must see what can be done with Sharply; if you'll step with me to my house, I'll send for a friend of mine, a man deeply skilled in the law, who we'll consult on the occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha! good; I'll do it, Friendly.—I'll hamper him, by the mass!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Ay, Sir John, we'll teach him to run away with heiresses!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Come along, Friendly; I'll hamper him.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: A Room in Friendly's House. Emily sitting alone reading. Enter to her Wellford. She rises.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: FORGIVE me, Madam, for thus intruding; but I am now come to take my leave of you, to bid you farewell, perhaps for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: My good wishes, Sir, shall always attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: And is that all, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: My prayers too, for your happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Unkind Emily! we met but yesterday, after a long, long absence; and is it thus we part to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: How did we meet yesterday? Wellford, remember that.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I thought, Madam, that a few rash words which jealous love forc'd me to utter might have been forgiven.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Think how you reproached me!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I was in hopes my sorrow for having offended you might—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: How you scorn'd, and left me!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Since my crime is too great for pardon, Madam, I can plead no more in my defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I could have born with patience every misfortune but that—the loss of parents, friends, fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: And can you, Emily, let that stubborn cruelty ba∣nish for ever from your presence a man who loves you as I do? Cold unrelenting creature! but I have done—Fare-you-well—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Wellford!—I forgive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Speak that again!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I pardon your unkindness to me; and now we'll part like friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Part! did you say, part! sooner with my eyes, my life, my very soul! No, Emily, no; since you forgive me, we never more will part!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Indeed we must.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: By heaven, we won't I What is there now wanting to compleat our felicity?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Ah! Wellford—your ardor makes you forget it now; but will you always speak thus, when the burden of a wife makes you feel the want of fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: For shame, my love, what a thought is that to mix with our new-kindled flames?—No, Emily, the world con∣tains not any thing that I would not give in exchange for you!—why do you hang your head?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Wellford, this generosity of yours has quite con∣quered my resentment, but it shall not overcome my resolu∣tion.—My heart is yours for ever.—Were I mistress of a crown, you should share it with me; but you shall not be partaker of my poverty: And now fare you well at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Barbarous creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: What! not reconciled yet? Well, you lovers have such preposterous notions!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Oh! Madam, all my hopes are now at an end! Emily has forgiven me, yet peremptorily refuses to be mine—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Well, that is to me now so unaccountable! Where is she? let me give her a lecture.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: She's just now retired to her chamber.—I thank you for your good intentions; but as I know your attempt will be in vain, I will not wait the issue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: You won't go till you see Mr. Friendly, sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P:
You'll pardon me, Madam; my own thoughts have rendered me unfit for any other company. I shall set
out immediately on my journey, and so—my good old friend, adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Now, as I live and breathe, I'll go to Emily, and rattle her for this!—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Changes to the Street before Friendly's House. As Wellford comes out, enter Sir John and Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Where now, Wellford?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I am this minute going to leave town, Friendly; and am glad I have met you to bid you good bye.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I have something to say to you; you must not go yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Indeed you must excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Sir John, do you insist on his staying; this is the gentleman I mentioned to you.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What the d—l, a lawyer in militaries! he holds well; but I have been so masqueraded, that e'gad I am surprised at nothing I see]—Pray, Sir, step in with us, I have material business with you; my name is Woodall.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I'll attend you, Sir.—[Friendly, what can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Mind that, Friendly.—A whimsical dog I suppose.]

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: But, dear Madam, would you have had me, thus situ∣ated, throw myself on a young man who has nothing but his sword to carve him out a maintenance?—Suppose we should have a family?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Fr.
SP.P:
Why, that's true too;—and to be sure you would have one; I was not near so young as you when I
married, and yet I have had nine children, no less I assure you, all alive, and christened.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Well, Madam, and does n't this—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I have but three left now;—the other six are better provided for, and very thankful I am that they are so.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Why, does n't this strengthen my argument against marrying Wellford? You know he is liberal to a fault, he loves pleasure too—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Young men to be sure will be gay; I remember Mr. Friendly, when he was a young man, why he—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: But, good Madam, you will not hear my reasons against a thing that you urge me to comply with, and yet are offering strong ones against it yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Lord, child, I have not said a syllable either for or against it!—To be sure, Wellford is as pretty a young man, and as good a young man—I have known him from his childhood; Mr. Friendly had the care of him when he was a boy; my Harry and he are just of an age.—I wou'd be glad he were married to a princess for that matter;—but what must be will be;—and as you are a prudent young creature, you may have your reasons, and so—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: May have! Why, Madam, I have been endeavour∣ing to give them to you, if you would hear them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: But I must needs say, if your rejecting him should drive the poor young man to desperation; for to tell you the truth he look'd so when he went away, that he made my very heart ake.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Is he gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Gone! ay, to be sure, I thought I had told you so before.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Poor Wellford!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: You might well say poor indeed, if you had seen him. I warrant you could sit down now, and cry your eyes out for vexation.—This comes of being positive;—but all's for the best, and so, my dear, you must think no more of it, but be merry and chearful, and—here will be Mr. Friendly home presently, and we shall hear—all about Sir John.—I vow here he is! and Sir John with him, as I live!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: My uncle!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Now, Sir John, are you satisfied?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: How came you here, Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: That's a very extraordinary question, Sir John; but I'll tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Hang me if you shall.—I'd rather remain in ig∣norance till doom's-day.—Let the girl speak for herself.—Was it Sharply who carried you away from my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: It was, Sir; and by Lady Woodall's contrivance: I am sorry to add, she had reasons for it, very disgraceful to herself and you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: There's for you, Sir John; very disgraceful reasons you find—a blessed bargain you have made of it truly—to go to bring such a woman to be a mistress of your family, and an aunt to your poor niece, and a mo∣ther to—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: My dear, don't teaze him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Answer me one question, Emily, and speak truth: Did that same lady of mine ever entertain a gallant or so, in my absence?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: She did, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Several, I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: But, Sir, out of respect to you, I now wish the story to be buried in silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why, she has turned out a very tygress, and be∣haved worse since he has own'd her, than she did before.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I have turned her off tho': why don't you tell that too, Friendly?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I am heartily glad of it. I knew it wou'd come to this.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I am sorry, Sir, that matters are gone so far, for the sake of your child.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Child! why, Friendly says it's none of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: There—I knew it.—Oh! Sir John, who wou'd have thought you cou'd have been made such a fool of! If you had taken Mr. Friendly's advice; but you were so obstinate, and so refractory, and thought yourself so wise—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Prithee, Madam, hold your tongue.—Friend∣ly, have you no command in your own house?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: And pray whose is this child, Sir John, that you are to father?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Your husband's, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: My husband, Sir John! he have an intrigue! Mr. Friendly have a correspondence with a loose woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why not? where wou'd be the wonder, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Sir John, you are very uncivil, let me tell you; and if you make nothing of such wickedness—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Heaven help me! my wickedness is a lasting to∣pic with these good sort of gentlewomen.—Pray, Friendly, desire you wife not to abuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: My dear, you wrong Sir John; he is very far from being wicked; he has indeed been grossly deceived.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Don't provoke me, Friendly, don't!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Provoke you, Sir John! does the vindicating your character provoke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: My character, Sir, is very well known; I want none of your palliations—if I have been an idle fellow, what's that to any man? perhaps I may reform, if I take it into my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: As you please for that, Sir John.—In the mean while, you must give me leave to bring in a friend of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Whom does Mr. Friendly mean? do you know, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Not I, protest, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Wickedness, and wickedness! I must be twitted forsooth every where I go with my wickedness!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I can't say but I am very sorry for you too, Sir John; you have been sadly abused, no one can deny that; but many an honest man has been made a fool of before now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: O—ds, Madam, who do you call an honest man?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Why, to do you justice, Mr. Friendly says, there is no great harm in you after all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Curse me, Madam, but you are very absurd, and I won't bear this!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Nay, Sir John, don't be in a passion; if you are a Dupe, it was not I that made you one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
Dupe! Dupe! 's-death, do you know what you are saying? do you know the meaning of that word,
that you use as familiarly indeed, as if—as if you knew what you said?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Yes, Sir John, I do know the meaning of it; you see I do; it means being made a fool of; and it means that you are a weak man, and a credulous man, and one that is easily overseen, and one that does n't know the dif∣ference between right and wrong, and one that thinks—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: That thinks you are possessed with ten thousand talking devils; and that I had rather be buried alive than listen to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: How now, Sir John! quarrelling with my wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: By my soul there's no bearing her, Friendly: I wish you were as well rid of her as I am of my plague.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Your plague! I scorn the comparison, Sir John; and—Lord, Mr. Wellford, are you here!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I thought he had been gone!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Why, I luckily intercepted him in his flight, and have, within this quarter of an hour, unravelled a mys∣tery to Sir John, and made him acquainted with this gen∣tleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Well, Captain, are you disposed to marry, not∣withstanding the sad example you have before you, in me and poor Friendly here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Poor Friendly! Sir John!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Don't worry him, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Sir John, if this lady can be prevailed on to ac∣cept of me—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What do you say, Emily? Friendly has given me a good account of this young fellow; and since he is willing to take you without a fortune, I have no objection; I'll hinder no body from playing the fool that has a mind to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Mr. Wellford, Sir, already knows my determination on that subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You won't have him then? a spirited wench, by my soul; I like her for that too.—How puzzled she looks tho', Friendly!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, I'll explain:—Emily, you are your uncle's sole heir. Sir John is convinced that his supposed son is an im∣postor, brought in by Mrs. Etherdown, to answer her own ends.—You will pardon me for making this experiment on your firmness of temper; and you, Wellford, for thus trying the sincerity of your love.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: So now, there's a surprize, you! egad, I think I carried on the joke very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Uncle, is it possible this can be true?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Faith I don't know whether it is possible or not; but I believe it to be fact. It has been a strange damn'd whimsical affair, from beginning to end.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Why, I am quite in amaze, Mr. Friendly!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Softly, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Wellford, here's my hand; and since my uncle ap∣proves—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, ay, with all my heart; and since I am my own master again, I'll try what living a little virtuously will do.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Well said, Sir John, resolved like a wise and a wor∣thy man; and let me tell you that is a better character than that of a fool and a rake; the first of which titles was all you got by affecting the last.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: None of your grave saws, Friendly; the wisest man may be deceived, if he deals with greater knaves than himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Uncle, if you will permit me to return to your house, I shall endeavour by the most dutiful behaviour—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, ay, you are all fine promisers.—I'll con∣sider of it;—but let nobody interpose, you know I hate that.—I'll have a bonfire to-night, and get drunk, for joy that I am rid of my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: And here's Wellford and I will get drunk for joy with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! brave Friendly! Ah! you rogue, you wou'd not let me be good, if I had a mind to it! but I will in spite of your teeth; I'll let you see I can be just what I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: There's no contending with you, Sir John, once you are resolved; that I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You allow that, I believe, Friendly; a deter∣min'd dog, that you'll grant.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Here are two criminals without, Sir John, that are afraid to appear in your presence; but since they have been so instrumental in detecting your wife's baseness—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! you mean Sharply and Rose—as precious a brace as ever were unhang'd—What wou'd you advise me to do with them, Friendly? I can transport them, at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: And I think you would do right, Sir John.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You do! then to let you see I am a better Chris∣tian than you, I will forgive them both. What do you say to me now, Friendly?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Faith, Sir John, I think you are even with her. Shall I call them? Who's there?
SP.STAGE: [Enter a Servant, Friendly whispers to him.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, do—poor paultry devils not worth my resentment;—tho' that Sharply is a sad rascal too, for I was always kind to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: And he has repaid your kindness, Sir John; for if it had not been for him, you would not be the free man that you now are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Faith, that's true—[Rose and Sharply come to the door.] Come in, you sneaking scoundrel you.—
What, my oracle! my adviser!—Hey, how's this? what the plague's become of your fool's face?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: That was but a mask, Sir John, which I wore oc∣casionally, for your entertainment, but have now no farther occasion for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: The d—l ow'd me a spite, and he has paid me with a vengeance;—so I am not angry with you, I don't think you worth it.—[Aside. Is not that right, Friendly?]

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Perfectly.—You see how much he's asham'd, poor bashful fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: As for you, Rose, you are a poor ignorant wench, and did as your mistress bid you. I suppose you did not think you were doing any great harm, so I forgive you too.—[Aside. Am I right, Friendly?]

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Never more so in your life.—Come, Mr. Sharply, since Sir John has pardon'd you your crimes against him, the rest of the company must own themselves obliged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I have promised that he shall not find me ungrate∣ful.

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Good Madam, if you wou'd but make Mr. Sharply keep his promise to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Did he promise you marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: He did indeed, Madam, or I am sure I should never—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And you want him to keep his word, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Rose.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Go, go, you silly slut, you are better as you are.—What do you think, Friendly?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: I think, Sir John, the woman's a fool who subjects herself for life to a man who must despise her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. John.
SP.P: Right.—What do you think, Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: I think, Sir John, the man's a greater fool that ventures to take a woman who he knows to be—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Stop, stop, stop; 's death! I have raised a wasp's nest about my own ears—What do you think your∣self, Sharply?

SP.SPEAKER: Sharp.
SP.P: I think, that having many sins to repent of, Sir John, I'll throw my vows to Mrs. Rose in amongst the rest; but will not impose such a pennance on myself as to fulfil them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Well said, Sharply. Egad he's no fool after all. Rose, you see the banns are forbid on all sides. No more matrimony, as you love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: No, no; no wedding, Rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: By no means, it would spoil both their fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Come, Sir John, if you weigh the good against the bad, you will find that you are arrived at a happy period of your life; for you have, within these four-and-twenty hours, acquired a piece of knowledge that you were ignorant of all your days before.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I have paid devilish dear for my knowledge tho', Friendly, and have learnt nothing by it, but that there is no truth in man or woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: You mistake me, Sir John; the knowledge I mean is that of knowing yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Ay, Sir John, know yourself, as Mr. Friendly says.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: And now, Sir John, I give you joy?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Of what, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: That you have recovered your senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I'd rather recover my money tho', by the mass!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Sir John, as you have lost nothing, but a little money and a bad wife, and this affair has ended so well, I assure you it will give me great satisfaction to relate it in the most particular and circumstantial manner to every body in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Prithee, Friendly, put a padlock on your wife's mouth, and then I shall be glad of her company and yours to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: And so I am neither to eat nor speak; I thank you for your invitation, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: We'll attend you, and celebrate Wellford's union and your separation together.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Agreed.—And to anticipate all Mrs. Friendly can say of me for the remainder of her life, I will here ac∣knowledge that I have been a fot, a fool, a dupe, a most egregious ass; that my wife was an artful wicked strumpet; that Sharply was an hypocritical rascal; Rose a cozening bag∣gage; poor Emily an injured innocence; the Captain there a gencrous lover; Friendly a zealous honest fellow; his wife a discerning and prudent matron; and for myself, that, after passing through the fiery trial, I am come out (it is to be hoped) a discreet and sober gentleman—Now, Madam, have you any thing more to add? I'll lay you fifty pounds, Friendly, she has not another word to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Take up his bett, Friendly, and I'll go your halves.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Done, Sir John!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: Sir John! I thought after all the money you had squander'd away, and all you were cheated of, and all the debts you have to pay, and all—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Well said, my dear; go on—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: S'death! Friendly, let me off for half my bett.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fr.
SP.P: No, no, Sir John, I have not half done.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Peace, peace, my dear! let us devote this day to mirth; and that Sir John may not be out of humour at his own lot, let him reflect how many are in the same predicament with himself, without ever find∣ing it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: True, Friendly; but I hope I may at least serve as a warning to my brethren.
SP.L: Taught by example better than by rules,
One dupe expos'd may save an hundred fools.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE, By a FRIEND. Spoken by Mrs. CLIVE.
DIV1.L: LAdies—methinks I hear you all complain,
Lord! here's the talking creature come again!
The men seem frighted—for 'tis on record
A prating female will have the last word.
But you're all out; for sure as you're alive,
Not Mrs. Friendly now, I'm Mrs. Clive;
No character from fiction will I borrow,
But if you please, I'll talk again to-morrow.
Then you conclude, from custom long in vogue,
That I come here to speak an Epilogue,
With satyr, humour, spirit, quite refin'd,
Double-entendre too, with wit combin'd,
Not for the ladies—but to please the men
All this you guess—and now you're out again;
For to be brief, our author bid me say
She tried, but cou'd n't get one to her play.
No Epilogue! why, Ma'am, you'll spoil your treat,
An Epilogue's the cordial after meat;
For when the feast is done, without all question,
They'll want liquors to help them to digestion;
And critics, when they find the banquet light,
Will come next time with better appetite;
So beg your friends to write—for faith 'tis hard,
If 'mongst them all you cannot find one bard.
She took the hint—Will you, good Sir? or you, Sir?
A sister scribbler! sure you can't refuse her!
Some lawyers try'd—not one cou'd make an end on't,
They'd now such work with plaintiff and defendant.
A poet tried, but he alleged for reason,
The Muses were so busy at this season,
In penning libels, politics and satyrs,
They had not leisure for such trifling matters.
What's to be done, she cry'd? can't you endeavour
To say some pretty thing?—I know you're clever.
I promis'd—but unable to succeed,
Beg you'll accept the purpose for the deed;
Tho' after three long hours in play-house coop'd,
I fear you'll say you've all been finely dup'd.
